node.title: Whale satellite tagging project blows migration assumptions out of water
node.alt: Small dinghy in background very close to southern right whale in foreground
node.description: Whales from New Zealand waters break all the rules on their migration path — heading west to Australia instead of to the South Pole.
node.content:
["It has\u00a0long been thought that the majestic and peaceful southern right whale headed\u00a0south to Antarctica after\u00a0frequenting Australia's\u00a0coast and the Auckland Islands south of New Zealand each winter.", "But is that where they really go?", "Until now, the whales' movements\u00a0away from the breeding grounds have\u00a0largely been a guessing game.", "A two-year international research project, called Tohora Voyages, tagged six New Zealand southern right whales (Eubalaena australis) in 2020 and\u00a011 more this August, to help assess the impact of climate change on the species.", "The results have been myth-busting.", "Almost all the whales headed west from New Zealand to the south of the Head of the Bight in South Australia, with some travelling even further to Western Australia and beyond, instead of the expected east and south route.\u00a0", "", "
Bill Wiremu, depicted as the light blue line, was\u00a0tracked for just over a year.(Supplied: Tohora Voyages website)
", "They've captured the hearts of New Zealanders who follow their migration almost daily online\u00a0and helped contribute five of the satellite tags through crowdfunding coordinated by marine conservation group Ocean Live.", "One of the whales tagged last year, nicknamed Bill Wiremu, was tracked for more than a year providing the most comprehensive data collected on a southern right whale in the world.", "Team Tohora, led by New Zealand scientist\u00a0Emma Carroll, is using genomics, stable isotopes, satellite tracking and habitat modelling to assess the recovery of the whale population and the impact of climate change.", "", "
Lead researcher Dr Emma Carroll says the research hopes to assess the future impact of climate change on the whales.(Supplied: University of Auckland Right Whale Research Team, taken by Richard Robinson under New Zealand Department of Conservation permit)
", "The New Zealand southern right whales were reduced from a pre-whaling population of 30,000 to just 40 individuals by the 1920s, and they now number more than 2000.", "There have been other tagging programs in the past, but the technology and techniques have improved to now provide quality data and the tags are staying on the whales longer.", "An earlier project by the South Australian Research and Development Institute at the Head of the Bight tagged nine whales but data\u00a0was only collected from three tags, also showing movement west and south in line with the New Zealand results.", "\"It's been fantastic to see the Aotearoa New Zealand whales voyaging so far and using so much of the Southern Ocean \u2014 they're travelling further than we ever expected,\" Dr Carroll said.", "\"It's also a positive that they seem to be feeding both south of Australia and along the coast of Antarctica \u2014 it could give the population resilience as, if one area has less prey, potentially the other area will have plenty of food.\"", "", "
Dr Virginia Andrews-Goff says the two-year research program has produced \"phenomenal\" data.(Supplied:Virginia Andrews-Goff)
", "Australia Antarctic Division senior marine mammal researcher Virginia Andrews-Goff said southern right whales were sentinels for climate change.", "\"This project aims to work out how well the southern right whales in the Auckland islands are recovering, where they're feeding, what they're feeding on, and how that will impact on their recovery within that climate change context,\" Dr\u00a0Andrews-Goff said.", "She said Bill Wiremu's movement was an exciting development.", "\"And so that in itself is surprising.", "\"Originally we had thought that we get some movements east but it just hasn't happened \u2014 they've moved west and south.\"", "Data from the satellite tags can be seen live on the Tohora Voyages website.", "", "
This is Bill Wiremu whose movements were recorded for over a year through a satellite tag.(Supplied: Tohora Voyages,\u00a0University of Auckland Right Whale Research Team, taken under New Zealand Department of Conservation permit)
", "The whales were tracked to the tropical\u2013subtropical convergence\u00a0zone, matching data from the South Australian Research and Development Institute in 2015 that showed the Australian south-west southern right whales also fed there.", "Dr Andrews-Goff said Bill Wiremu tracked west halfway to South Africa before heading south to Antarctica and back to New Zealand and the Bight.", "\"It's possibly one of the best satellite tracks I've ever seen.\"", "Live Ocean chief executive Sally Paterson said Bill Wiremu's adventures were captivating.", "\"Everyone who donated to the tags and followed the journey were blown away by the story and voyage of these whales and the scientists who are working so hard to protect them,\" Ms Paterson said.", "The project is expected to feed into the management aspects of the International Whaling Commission in the Southern Ocean Research Partnership.", "Dr Andrews-Goff said drone monitoring was also helpful.", "\"They flew drones above the southern right whales to look at body condition, but also to use the imagery as\u00a0a proxy to see what kind of human interactions these animals are having.", "\"They\u00a0detected a bit of scarring from entanglements and from vessel strike using\u00a0the drones.\"", "", "
Researchers encounter snow while tagging at the Auckland Islands south of New Zealand.\u00a0(Supplied:\u00a0University of Auckland Right Whale Research Team, taken under New Zealand Department of Conservation permit)
"]
